column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-north-carolina-lgbt-idUSKCN11P26D	Charlotte not budging on ordinance that spurred North Carolina bathroom law	"
By Colleen Jenkins
| WINSTON-SALEM
WINSTON-SALEM
column3: North Carolina
column4: refused on Monday to back off an ordinance that had aimed to expand anti-discrimination protections for gay and transgender people in the state's largest city but also sparked a controversial state law.The Republican leaders of North Carolina's legislature said in a statement late on Sunday they believed their colleagues would support repealing the law that voided the city ordinance - if Charlotte made the first move.   North Carolina's Republican governor and lawmakers blame Charlotte for spurring the state measure
column5: which has drawn rebuke from major companies and sports organizations since it was passed in March. The state law
column6: known as House Bill 2
column7: requires transgender people to use publicly owned bathrooms that correspond with the gender on their birth certificate and bars local ordinances protecting lesbian
column9: bisexual and transgender people from discrimination.A spokesman for Governor Pat McCrory told local media last week McCrory would call a special session for legislators to consider a repeal of H.B. 2 if Charlotte rescinded its ordinance.

column1: But Charlotte Mayor Jennifer Roberts
column3: said the city had no plans to reconsider the ordinance at a council meeting Monday night.""We appreciate the state wanting to find a solution to the challenges we are facing and applaud the governor for recognizing the state should overturn H.B. 2
column4: which the state can do at any time without any action from the City of Charlotte
column5: Roberts said in a statement.

column1: Calls for a repeal of the state law mounted last week after the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) and Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) pulled a total of 17 championship sporting events from North Carolina in protest of it.Previously
column2: the National Basketball Association relocated its 2017 All-Star Game from Charlotte. Entertainers
column3: including Bruce Springsteen
column4: canceled concerts and companies such as Deutsche Bank scrapped plans to add jobs in the state over objections to the law.Senate leader Phil Berger on Monday questioned whether Roberts was seeking to ""prolong this debate for political reasons - regardless of the impact on Charlotte and our state's business community.""

column1: LGBT advocates applauded the Charlotte mayor for standing firm
column3: tourism and hospitality groups urged elected officials to find a compromise to end the economic fallout.An Elon University Poll released on Monday found that almost half of likely voters in the state oppose H.B. 2. But the survey also showed McCrory leading Democratic challenger Roy Cooper by about 49 percent to 46 percent and indicated that some opponents of the law still planned to vote for the incumbent.     (Reporting by Colleen Jenkins; Editing by Dan Grebler)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-egypt-idUSKCN11O109	Clinton
column2: Trump to both meet with Egyptian president at U.N.	"

column1: By James Oliphant
| WHITE PLAINS
WHITE PLAINS
column2: N.Y. An adviser to U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's campaign said on Sunday that Trump will meet with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi on Monday during the United Nations General Assembly
column3: just as Hillary Clinton
column4: the Democratic presidential nominee
column5: is also scheduled to do. Clinton
column6: who faces Trump in the Nov. 8 election
column7: announced last week that she would meet both with Sisi and Ukraine President Petro Poroshenko in bilateral sessions expected to take place late on Monday. A foreign policy advisor to Trump
column9: told Reuters on Sunday that Trump would also have talks with Sisi on the same day.For Trump
column10: a New York real estate magnate and reality-TV show host who has never held political office
column11: it marks the second time in recent weeks he has tried to burnish his foreign-policy credentials to compete with Clinton
column12: the former Secretary of State under President Barack Obama and a U.S. Senator from New York. Trump ventured to Mexico late last month to meet with President Enrique Pena Nieto to discuss border security between the two nations.

column1: But afterward
column2: both sides quickly accused the other of not accurately representing the scope of the conversations
column3: with Trump insisting that the subject of which country would pay for a proposed wall between the two nations never came up
column4: and Pena Nieto saying that his country would never agree to finance it.Egypt remains in flux after the country's chaotic revolution in 2011 that deposed President Hosni Mubarak
column5: a movement that the Obama administration supported. Then-Secretary Clinton has since written that she advised a more conservative approach than the White House ultimately took toward Mubarak's exit.

column1: Egypt's Islamist President
column3: was eventually supplanted by Sisi
column4: the nation's former defense minister and a secularist
column5: in 2013.Some Republicans in the U.S. House of Representatives have since accused the Obama administration of abandoning its support of Egypt's government in its battle against Islamic militants.

column1: Trump has called for aggressive measures in combating the threat of Islamic State forces in Iraq and Syria and has proposed blocking immigrants from countries that he says pose a threat to the United States. Earlier in his campaign
column2: he suggested banning all Muslims from entering the country.Clinton's meeting with Ukraine President Poroshenko also is likely to be provocative given the reportedly close ties between Trump's campaign and the administration of Russian President Vladimir Putin. Russia annexed the Crimean peninsula
column3: considered part of Ukraine
column4: in 2014.  (Reporting by James Oliphant; Editing by Sandra Maler)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-obama-idUSKCN11P04D	Obama tells Clinton fundraiser U.S. still grapples with powerful women	"
By Jeff Mason
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK U.S. society is uncomfortable with powerful women and that is why the United States has not yet elected a woman president
column2: President Barack Obama said on Sunday.Obama
column3: who is eager to see fellow Democrat Hillary Clinton succeed him in office
column4: told a fundraiser for her in New York that the election between his former secretary of state and Republican businessman Donald Trump should not be close.However
column5: political polarization in the country would make it tight
column6: he said.The first African-American U.S. president then told the group of donors why he thought a woman had never held the office. ""There's a reason why we haven't had a woman president
column7: he said. ""We as a society still grapple with what it means to see powerful women. And it still troubles us in a lot of ways
column8: unfairly. And that expresses itself in all sorts of ways.""

column1: Obama has often spoken about the role of strong women in his life
column3: grandmother
column4: wife and daughters. Polls have tightened between Clinton
column5: a former U.S. senator and first lady
column6: and Trump

column1: This should not be a close election
column3: Obama said. ""And the reason it will be is not because of Hillary's flaws
column4: but rather because
column5: structurally
column6: we've become a very polarized society
column7: he said.The president has not hidden his disdain for Trump
column8: who was one of the leaders of the movement that questioned whether Obama was born in the United States. Trump conceded on Friday that Obama was U.S. born.Obama told the donors that Trump was unlike the two candidates he faced in the 2008 and 2012 general elections.

column1: When I ran against John McCain
column3: but I couldn't say that he was not qualified to be president of the United States
column4: Obama said of his 2008 opponent. ""I couldn't say that electing Mitt Romney would be an unmitigated disaster. This guy (Trump) is not qualified to be president."" (Reporting by Jeff Mason; Editing by Paul Tait)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-new-jersey-bridgegate-idUSKCN11O0BZ	As 'Bridgegate' trial begins
By Joseph Ax
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK New Jersey Governor Chris Christie is not expected to attend the trial this week of two former associates charged in the 2013 ""Bridgegate"" scandal
column2: but the failed Republican presidential hopeful's shadow will loom over the proceedings.Opening statements are scheduled for Monday in federal court in Newark
column3: New Jersey. Bill Baroni and Bridget Anne Kelly are charged with conspiracy and fraud in a nine-count indictment alleging they arranged lane closings that caused gridlock on the heavily traveled George Washington Bridge.The resulting traffic delayed commuters for hours and left emergency vehicles slow in responding to 911 calls. Prosecutors said the two defendants planned the lane closures to take revenge on a mayor who refused to endorse Christie for re-election.The governor
column4: at one time a leading Republican presidential hopeful
column5: has not been charged in the scandal that nevertheless helped torpedo his hopes for nomination to the White House in 2016.In the three years since the scandal broke
column6: Christie has repeatedly denied any knowledge of the plan to disrupt traffic on the world's busiest road bridge
column7: despite speculation to the contrary.The trial could finally provide a definitive answer to the question of whether he knew about the alleged plot

column1: Bridgegate"" took place after Democratic Fort Lee Mayor Mark Sokolich declined to endorse the governor's reelection campaign in 2013. Christie was seeking support from local mayors to demonstrate bipartisan backing for a Republican governor in a Democratic-leaning state
column2: part of an effort to position himself for a 2016 White House bid.Prosecutors say the lane closures were ordered in September 2013 by Kelly
column3: Christie's then deputy chief of staff; Baroni
column4: then deputy executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey; and David Wildstein
column5: another Christie ally at the Port Authority who has since pleaded guilty. The GW carries more than 250
column6: 000 vehicles a day across the Hudson River between New Jersey and Manhattan.The trio concocted a cover story
column7: saying the closure was part of a traffic study
column8: prosecutors contend. The shutdown lasted four days
column9: while Baroni and Wildstein ignored increasingly frantic messages from the mayor

column1: The ruse fell apart under scrutiny from journalists and the Democratic-controlled state legislature. In January 2014
column2: emails and text messages were publicly disclosed that showed the officials' involvement
column3: including an Aug. 13
column5: email in which Kelly told Wildstein: ""Time for some traffic problems in Fort Lee.""Wildstein
column6: who is expected to be a star government witness
column7: has previously said there is evidence that Christie was aware of the lane closures when they occurred.Jurors also may hear from Kelly and Baroni
column8: as lawyers for both defendants have said they plan to testify in their own defense.

column1: The defense has suggested it will point the finger at others
column3: in arguing that Kelly and Baroni would never have acted on their own.In a pretrial motion
column4: a lawyer for Baroni revealed that a former Christie aide said in a text message that the governor ""flat-out lied"" when he said during a 2013 press conference that none of his senior staff were involved in the scandal. A spokesman for the governor has said the text message does not disprove Christie's contention that he was unaware of the plot.Since abandoning his own candidacy for president
column5: Christie has become one of Republican nominee Donald Trump's most visible supporters. (Reporting by Joseph Ax; Editing by Scott Malone and David Gregorio)"

column1: WASHINGTON Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton on Sunday condemned what she called the ""apparent terrorist attacks"" in Minnesota
column2: New Jersey and New York. The three attacks on Saturday involved a stabbing in a Minnesota mall that wounded nine people
column3: a bombing in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood that injured 29 and a pipe bomb explosion in New Jersey.

column1: (Reporting by Alana Wise; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

By Alana Wise
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Donald Trump's vice presidential running mate
column3: said he views former vice president Dick Cheney as a role model for the No. 2 job in the administration.""I frankly hold Dick Cheney in really high regard in his role as vice president and as an American
column4: Pence said in an interview on ABC's ""This Week"" that was taped on Saturday and aired on Sunday.""Vice President Cheney had experience in Congress as I do and he was very active in working with members of the House and the Senate
column5: Pence said.

column1: Cheney
column2: vice president to Republican George W. Bush
column3: was known for wielding strong influence in the administration
column4: particularly in Bush's first term. Cheney was a forceful advocate of the decision to invade Iraq and some aides to Bush have said they believed he wielded too much power.

column1: Pence said he had spoken with Trump about areas he would focus on as vice president but said he did not want to discuss their private conversations.Cheney has said he will support Trump in the Nov. 8 election against Democrat Hillary Clinton.
(Reporting by Alana Wise; Editing by Caren Bohan and Bill Trott)"

column2: wrote Michael Busk of the St. Vincent Health

column5: has released a note from his doctor saying that he
column6: too

column12: prompting her campaign to disclose that she had been diagnosed with non-contagious

column1: Busk said in the letter dated Thursday that he last examined Pence
column2: who is the governor of Indiana

column1: Pence exercises four days a week

column4: a common form of skin cancer

9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN11M2A4	Race tightens in projected U.S. Electoral College vote: Reuters/Ipsos	"
By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK An election analysis conducted in the Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project shows that the race has tightened considerably over the past few weeks
column2: with Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump projected to win Florida
column3: an essential battleground state
column4: if the election were held today.  The project
column5: which is based on a weekly tracking poll of more than 15
column6: 000 Americans
column7: shows that the 2016 presidential race could end in a photo finish on Nov. 8
column8: with the major-party candidates running nearly even in the Electoral College
column9: the body that ultimately selects the president.  The States of the Nation project
column10: which delivers a weekly tally of support for the candidates in every state
column11: shows that the race has tightened in several traditional battlegrounds. Pennsylvania has been moved from a likely win for Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton to a tossup; Ohio has been moved from a tossup to a likely win for Clinton. And Florida is now considered a likely win for the Republican nominee
column12: with 50 percent support for Trump to 46 percent support for Clinton.If the election were held today
column13: the project estimates that Clinton has a 60 percent chance of winning by 18 electoral votes. Last week
column14: the project estimated that Clinton had a 83 percent chance of winning the election. In a separate national Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll
column15: Clinton continues to lead Trump by 4 percentage points
column16: and her recent bout with pneumonia doesn't appear to have scared away her supporters.  The national Sept. 9-15 tracking poll showed that 42 percent of likely voters supported Clinton while 38 percent backed Trump. Clinton
column17: who has mostly led Trump in the poll since the Democratic and Republican national conventions ended in July
column18: regained the advantage this week after her lead briefly faded in late August.     Clinton has an advantage among minorities
column22: and those with moderate political leanings. Trump has an advantage with whites
column25: and people who are nearing retirement age.

column1: LITTLE CONCERN OVER CANDIDATES' HEALTH
Overall
column2: Americans appear to be relatively uninspired by their choices for president with less than eight weeks to go before the election. One out of every five likely voters said they do not support Clinton or Trump for president. In comparison
column3: about one out of every 10 likely voters wouldn't support Obama or Republican challenger Mitt Romney at a similar point in the 2012 presidential campaign.Respondents took the survey after video surfaced of Clinton nearly collapsing at a Sept. 11 memorial in New York on Sunday. Her campaign later said she had a non-contagious
column4: bacterial form of pneumonia.

column1: The video sparked a renewed discussion about the health of both candidates. Trump
column3: would be the oldest president to take office
column4: while Clinton
column6: would be the second oldest.Clinton and Trump candidates have since released details of their personal health. Clinton's doctors said her physical exam was normal
column8: and that she was in excellent mental condition. Trump released a note from his doctor saying that he was in ""excellent physical health.""Americans do not appear to be overly concerned with the health of either candidate. According to a separate question in the poll conducted this week
column9: most American adults said the issue would make ""no difference"" to how they voted.

column1: A negligible percentage of Clinton supporters said concerns about her health made them ""less likely"" to vote for her.Clinton led all candidates in a four-way poll of likely voters that included Gary Johnson of the Libertarian Party and Jill Stein of the Green Party. Seven percent of respondents supported Johnson
column2: and 2 percent backed Stein. The Reuters/Ipsos poll is conducted online in English in all 50 states. The latest horserace poll surveyed 1
column3: 579 likely voters over the past week. The question on the candidates' health surveyed 1
column4: 179 American adults from Sept. 12-16. Both polls had a credibility interval
column5: a measure of accuracy
column6: of 3 percentage points. National polls have produced varying measurements of support during the 2016 campaign for Clinton and Trump. The differences are partly due to the fact that some polls
column8: try to include only likely voters
column9: while others include all registered voters. The Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll gathers responses every day and reports results twice a week
column10: so it often detects trends in sentiment before most other polls. Polling aggregators
column11: which calculate averages of major polls
column12: have shown that Clinton's lead over Trump has been shrinking this month. The most recent individual polls put Clinton's advantage at 1 or 2 percentage points. (Editing by Ross Colvin and Mary Milliken)"
